text: I stepped forward, keeping my voice as gentle as possible: “Friend, she’s just a traveler—”
Before I could finish, the drunk glared at me and shoved me hard. Wine splashed everywhere, his fist slammed onto the counter, and the wood gave a dull crack.
I stumbled back several steps, knocking over a few glasses that shattered loudly in the quiet tavern.
“Stop pretending to be a good man!” he shouted, reeking of alcohol. “Everyone in this town looks down on me, don’t they?!”
His eyes were clouded and wild, fury burning within like a trapped beast as he advanced step by step.
I raised a hand, trying to speak again—when suddenly the wind outside howled, slamming the tavern door open with a loud bang.
The fire in the hearth was pressed low by the gust, its light flickering violently. Everyone held their breath.
Cold air swept in through the doorway, carrying with it snow and the scent of metal.
The cloaked woman’s gaze fell upon the drunk. Calm—yet sharper than the winter wind.
The drunk opened his mouth to curse, but it was as if an invisible hand clutched his throat. The air froze.
My heart tightened. The fire rekindled, its glow flickering—her silver hair glimmered in the light like the reflection of a blade.
She raised her hand and flicked her finger lightly. The bottle left the drunk’s grasp, traced a cold arc through the air, and landed neatly in her palm.
Everything went silent. Even the drunk himself froze, as if his rage had been sucked out of him.
In that moment, I realized—the entire tavern was still. Even the flames no longer swayed.
Her voice sounded softly: “Enough.”
The drunk’s Adam’s apple moved. His lips trembled, but no sound came out. He staggered back a step, nearly falling.
Breathing heavily, he muttered a curse, then pushed the door open and stumbled out into the storm.
The door slammed shut behind him, snow swirling in the fading gust. The tavern fell silent again.
I took a deep breath, my chest still burning. Her gaze swept over me—no blame, only a faint trace of pity.
I opened my mouth, but no words came out. The fire danced once more, its light reflected in her eyes like a deep, endless lake of snow.
